In addition to my professional skills, my career has led me to explore various areas of knowledge that have left a mark on my worldview. Here, I describe some areas that have particularly captured my attention, including some references to my own work:
:::

### Academia-Industry Collaboration (AIC)
::: justified 
Building bridges to increase the impact of ideas ğŸ“ğŸ¤ ğŸ’¼ 

The transfer of knowledge between academic and business organizations to promote innovation is the main subject I have been working on for the last 5 or 6 years. So far it has been a process which involved navigating multiple perspectives, continuously increasing in its complexity:

* My interest in the subject appeared thanks to the Economics of Knowledge course of my Master's, where a collegue and I explored the role of public research institutions in catching-up processes by analyzing the the case of India.

* The exploration of the subject continued with my Master's thesis, titled "University-Industry Relationship through Knowledge Transfer Organizations in Developing Countries: Evidence from an Argentinian Local Innovation Ecosystem"

* The recent submission of PhD Thesis, titled "Understanding Knowledge Dynamics Across Modes of Academia-Industry Collaboration:
A Comprehensive Mixed-Method Analysis within the I-Space Framework: Lessons from San Carlos de Bariloche, Argentina", represent the last and most profound stage of this process.

:::

### Knowledge Management and Organizational Learning
::: justified
ğŸ˜ï¸ Designing strategies for the collective production of knowledge ğŸ“¦

A critical topic I studied for my doctorate and which motivates me to approach the implementation of knowledge. 

* Since I have not contributed much to the field so far, I should highlight the theoretical framework developed by Boisot [-@boisot1995] for understanding information and knowledge flows in social settings: the *Information Space* or *I-Space*. In my [**blog**](blog.qmd), I am now trying to synthesize and use this framework to analyze the conjuncture.

* Coding, abstraction, and diffusion are three key dimensions used to analyze the ongoing production of knowledge [@boisot2011].

* Besides the I-Space, other perspectives have also shaped my understanding of the field [e.g., @alavi2001; @cetina1999; @march1991; @nonaka1995; @polanyi1958; @teece1997].
:::

### Economics, Institutions, and Culture
::: justified
ğŸ’¼ Exploring the socio-cultural foundations of economic and human behavior ğŸ“– 

How culture and institutional arrangements define the management of resources, information, and knowledge? 

* Besides exploring Academia-Industry Collaborations, with another classmate of the master we made an analysis of hackerspace and makerspaces based on Ostrom's [-@ostrom1990] idea of commons.

* Beyond my limited contribution to the subject, a few approaches worth mentioning are innovation systems [@cooke2001; @etzkowitz2000; @lundvall1988; @nelson1993], open innovation [@chesbrough2003; @vonhippel2005], commons [@allen2016; @hess2007; @kostakis2015; @ostrom1990], and information economics [@boisot1998].

:::

### Platforms and Digitalization
::: justified
ğŸ—‚ï¸ Navigating the Digital Age ğŸ“Š

The continuous proliferation of information and communication technologies (ICTs) has a strong impact on the production of knowledge and information.

* With my PhD supervisor we've broadly explored the [foundations of digital platforms and their classification](https://comein.uoc.edu/divulgacio/oikonomics/_recursos/documents/14/canals-hulskamp_Oikonomics14_esp.pdf).

* I'm particularly drawn to theoretical perspectives like Gawer [-@gawer2020]. I believe understanding how these platforms are reshaping economic and social interactions is fundamental. 
:::
